BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Avalanche danger 4- high above the forest line
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The period with snowfall continues, and even between Saturday and Sunday morning 10-20 cm of snow fell, with snow/rain limits at 700-900 m altitude. Precipitation was heaviest in the Vicenza Prealps and southern Dolomites. Temperatures and weather are expected to worsen again on Monday with 5-15 cm of snow in the Dolomites at 2000 m and 5-15 in the Vicenza Prealps at 1500 m. The snowpack is weakly consolidated on many steep slopes beyond the forest line. Avalanche danger is 4-strong above 1900 m elevation and 3-marked at lower elevations. Spontaneous fresh snow avalanche releases, even large ones, are to be expected along steep couloirs and open slopes. In individual situations, avalanches may even reach low altitudes. Triggered slab avalanche releases are possible already with weak overload (single skier, snowshoe hiker). Glide avalanches are expected along steep grassy slopes below 1800 m elevation in sunny exposures.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: New snowfall is expected on Monday and the danger will be 4-strong above the forest line and 3-marked at lower elevations. Spontaneous detachments of even large fresh snow avalanches are to be expected along steep slopes and usual gullies. Triggered detachments of wind-caused soft slabs are possible already with weak overburden, in all exposures. Slip avalanches are expected along grassy steep slopes below 1800 m elevation in sunny exposures. Avalanche danger may still affect and localized man-made areas habitually exposed to avalanche danger. Conditions for snow hiking are favoring fresh snow but it is recommended to be accompanied by mountain professionals as there are unstable conditions that need to be well identified in order to safely circumvent them. It is recommended to have self-rescue equipment (ARTVA, shovel and probe) in tow and active

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: During the second half of the night as the snowfall becomes more intense there will be an increase in the avalanche danger to level 4 (high).
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
In particular along the border with France over a wide area 30 to 50 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall until the evening above approximately 1000 m. As a consequence of low temperatures, snowfall and the occasionally moderate southeasterly wind, a precarious avalanche situation will develop.
These weather conditions will bring about a weakening of the near-surface layers from the second half of the night in all aspects.
The cold fresh snow and the wind slabs can be released very easily, especially on steep slopes. Remotely triggered avalanches are possible.
Snow sport participants with little experience in the assessment of avalanche danger should remain on the open pistes. Backcountry touring calls for very extensive experience in the assessment of avalanche danger and careful route selection.
Natural avalanches:
Dry slab avalanches and dry loose snow avalanches are likely to occur already in the early morning. Powder avalanches are possible, even large ones in isolated cases. They can be triggered in the new snow and wind slab layers and can reach as far as the valley bottom, in the regions exposed to heavier precipitation especially.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
30 to 50 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall until the evening above approximately 1000 m.
The moderate wind will transport the new snow. The fresh snow and the wind slabs are bonding poorly with the old snowpack.
The wind slabs of the last few days will be covered with new snow and therefore difficult to recognise.
Since Friday in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain many small and medium-sized avalanches were released.
On the night between Thursday and Friday: Numerous medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large dry slab avalanches have been released on wind-loaded slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Little snow will fall on Tuesday. The danger will decrease gradually.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights:
A lot of snow has fallen in some regions.
In the regions exposed to heavier precipitation the avalanche danger is higher.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The fresh snow as well as the wind slabs represent the main danger. This applies in particular in the regions exposed to heavier precipitation.
In all aspects large and, in isolated cases, very large avalanches are possible as a consequence of new snow and strong wind. The new snow and wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant in all aspects. In addition the barely recognisable wind slabs should be taken into account.
As a consequence of warming during the day and the solar radiation, the likelihood of loose snow slides being released will increase gradually in particular on steep sunny slopes. Gliding avalanches can also occur.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The fresh snow as well as the resulting wind slabs remain for the foreseeable future prone to triggering.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Some snow will fall over a wide area.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Weakly bonded old snow represents the main danger. Fresh wind slabs require caution.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Avalanches can be triggered in the old snowpack and reach large size in isolated cases in particular on very steep west, north and east facing slopes. Such avalanche prone locations are to be found above approximately 2400 m.

Above the tree line the wind slabs will increase in size additionally. Even single winter sport participants can release avalanches in some places, including medium-sized ones, especially on steep shady slopes. The number and size of avalanche prone locations will increase with altitude. In the regions of the north exposed to the foehn wind such avalanche prone locations are more prevalent.

On steep grassy slopes medium-sized gliding avalanches are possible, especially on sunny slopes below approximately 2400 m.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Up to 10 cm of snow fell on Sunday. In the southwest 5 to 15 cm of snow will fall on Monday. The southerly wind will transport the new snow.

In some cases new snow and wind slabs are lying on a weakly bonded old snowpack, in particular on steep west, north and east facing slopes above approximately 2400 m.

Fresh wind slabs are lying on soft layers especially on shady slopes.
The wind slabs are covered with new snow in some cases and therefore difficult to recognise. In the regions exposed to snowfall this applies in particular in the south.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The conditions will prevent a rapid stabilisation of the snowpack. In addition further gliding avalanches are to be expected.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Weakly bonded old snow requires caution. Loose snow avalanches and gliding avalanches are still possible.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Weak layers in the old snowpack can be released in some places even by individual winter sport participants. The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular on west, north and east facing slopes above approximately 2400 m. Avalanches can reach large size in isolated cases.
Isolated whumpfing sounds can indicate the danger.

Fresh wind slabs can be released easily in particular on very steep shady slopes above the tree line, caution is to be exercised in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in pass areas. Such avalanche prone locations are sometimes covered with new snow and are therefore difficult to recognise.
On extremely steep slopes small to medium-sized loose snow avalanches are possible.

On steep grassy slopes small and medium-sized gliding avalanches are possible, especially below approximately 2400 m.

Backcountry touring and other off-piste activities call for careful route selection.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Over a wide area 5 to 15 cm of snow fell on Sunday. In some localities up to 10 cm of snow will fall on Monday, in particular in the west. The wind will be moderate adjacent to ridgelines.

The new snow and wind slabs of the last few days are lying on the unfavourable surface of an old snowpack in particular on west to north to east facing aspects above approximately 2400 m.
Fresh wind slabs are lying on soft layers on near-ridge shady slopes. The wind slabs are covered with new snow in some cases and therefore difficult to recognise.
The covering of new snow is fairly homogeneous; its surface consists of loosely bonded snow.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The avalanche danger will persist. Weakly bonded old snow represents the main danger.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The fresh snow and the wind slabs that are forming during the snowfall represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Over a wide area 15 to 30 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall above approximately 1800 m. The wind will be moderate.
The fresh wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant and generally at intermediate and high altitudes. They are to be found especially adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls. The avalanche prone locations are barely recognisable because of the poor visibility.
As a consequence of the snowfall dry avalanches are possible, even large ones.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The moderate wind will transport the new snow. In some places new snow and wind slabs are lying on the soft surface of an old snowpack. Faceted weak layers exist in the old snowpack on steep shady slopes.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: New snow and wind slabs require caution. As a consequence of the snowfall the avalanche prone locations will become more prevalent from the late morning.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: 20 to 50 cm of snow will fall above approximately 1800 m. The moderate wind will transport the new snow. The sometimes deep wind slabs can be released even by a single winter sport participant in particular on steep shady slopes above approximately 2000 m. This applies in particular in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain in particular at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The new snow is deposited on bare ground over a wide area. This applies in particular on sunny slopes, as well as at low and intermediate altitudes. In some places new snow and wind slabs are lying on a hard crust. As a consequence of snowfall and the occasionally strong wind, fresh snow drift accumulations will form. The snowpack will become increasingly unstable.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind slabs and weakly bonded old snow require caution.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Single winter sport participants can release avalanches very easily, including medium-sized ones. The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular on very steep shady slopes above approximately 2100 m. Caution is to be exercised in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls. The avalanche prone locations are covered with new snow and are barely recognisable, even to the trained eye. Avalanches can in isolated cases be triggered in the old snowpack and reach quite a large size.
On steep grassy slopes medium-sized gliding avalanches are possible.
Gradual increase in avalanche danger as a consequence of the precipitation. Medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large loose snow avalanches are possible as the day progresses.
Backcountry touring and other off-piste activities call for great caution and restraint.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Up to 60 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen since Friday above approximately 1400 m. The strong wind has transported some snow. The new snow and wind slabs are poorly bonded with the old snowpack. The new snow and wind slabs of the last few days are lying on the unfavourable surface of an old snowpack above approximately 2400 m.
Over a wide area 30 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall on Monday above approximately 900 m. The wind will be moderate to strong adjacent to ridgelines.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment:
The weather conditions will prevent a rapid stabilisation of the snowpack.
Above approximately 700 m snow will fall on Tuesday over a wide area. Gradual increase in avalanche danger as a consequence of the precipitation. More frequent loose snow avalanches are to be expected, but they can be quite large, in the regions exposed to a lot of new snow especially on very steep slopes.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: New snow and wind slabs. As a consequence of the snowfall the prevalence and size of these avalanche prone locations will increase from the early morning.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: 30 to 50 cm of snow will fall. The sometimes strong wind will transport the new snow significantly. Large natural avalanches are possible in the regions exposed to precipitation. The fresh wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant in particular on steep shady slopes above approximately 1800 m. This applies in particular in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain. The avalanche prone locations are barely recognisable because of the poor visibility.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The new snow is deposited on bare ground over a wide area. This applies in particular on sunny slopes, as well as at low and intermediate altitudes. In some places new snow and wind slabs are lying on a hard crust. As a consequence of snowfall and the strong wind, snow drift accumulations will form. The snowpack will become increasingly unstable.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The fresh snow and the wind slabs that are forming during the snowfall represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
In all regions over a wide area 20 to 30 cm of snow will fall until the evening above approximately 1000 m. As a consequence of low temperatures, snowfall and the occasionally moderate southeasterly wind, an unfavourable avalanche situation will develop.
The cold fresh snow and the wind slabs can be released very easily. Even single snow sport participants can release avalanches easily,, also on steep slopes. Backcountry touring calls for meticulous route selection.
Natural avalanches:
These weather conditions will bring about a weakening of the near-surface layers in all aspects.
Dry slab avalanches and dry loose snow avalanches are likely to occur already in the early morning. Dry avalanches are possible as the day progresses, even large ones in isolated cases, in particular along the border with Switzerland and in the regions neighbouring those that are subject to danger level 4 (high).
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
20 to 30 cm of snow will fall until the evening above approximately 1000 m.
The moderate wind will transport the new snow. The fresh snow and the wind slabs are bonding poorly with the old snowpack.
The wind slabs of the last few days will be covered with new snow and therefore difficult to recognise.
20 to 30 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, fell on Thursday above approximately 2000 m.
The old snowpack is favourably layered.
At low and intermediate altitudes only a little snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Some snow will fall on Tuesday. The danger will persist.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: New snow and wind slabs require caution.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: 20 to 30 cm of snow will fall above approximately 1500 m. The sometimes deep wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant in isolated cases in particular on steep shady slopes above approximately 2000 m. This applies in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in pass areas in particular at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions. The avalanche prone locations are barely recognisable because of the poor visibility.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The new snow is deposited on bare ground over a wide area. This applies in particular on sunny slopes, as well as at low and intermediate altitudes. In some places new snow and wind slabs are lying on a hard crust. As a consequence of snowfall and the occasionally strong wind, fresh snow drift accumulations will form. The snowpack will become increasingly unstable.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: As a consequence of the snowfall the avalanche prone locations will become more prevalent.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: In the afternoon as the snowfall becomes more intense there will be an increase in the avalanche danger to level 3 (considerable).
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
In all regions over a wide area 25 to 50 cm of snow will fall until the evening above approximately 1000 m.
As a consequence of low temperatures, snowfall and the moderate southeasterly wind, an unfavourable avalanche situation will develop in the afternoon.
The fresh wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant and generally at intermediate and high altitudes.
These avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain. They are barely recognisable because of the poor visibility.
Natural avalanches:
As a consequence of the snowfall dry avalanches are possible in the evening, even medium-sized ones.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
20 to 40 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall until the evening above approximately 1000 m.
The moderate wind will transport the new snow. The fresh snow and the wind slabs are bonding poorly with the old snowpack.
10 to 20 cm of snow fell on Thursday above approximately 1900 m.
The old snowpack will be in most cases well bonded.
Snow depths vary greatly at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions, depending on the infuence of the wind.
At low and intermediate altitudes only a little snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Some snow will fall on Tuesday. The danger will persist.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: In the afternoon as the snowfall becomes more intense there will be an increase in the avalanche danger to level 3 (considerable).
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
In all regions over a wide area 25 to 50 cm of snow will fall until the evening above approximately 1000 m.
As a consequence of low temperatures, snowfall and the moderate southeasterly wind, an unfavourable avalanche situation will develop in the afternoon.
The fresh wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant and generally at intermediate and high altitudes.
These avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain. They are barely recognisable because of the poor visibility.
Natural avalanches:
As a consequence of the snowfall dry avalanches are possible in the evening, even medium-sized ones.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
20 to 40 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall until the evening above approximately 1000 m.
The moderate wind will transport the new snow. The fresh snow and the wind slabs are bonding poorly with the old snowpack.
10 to 20 cm of snow fell on Thursday above approximately 1900 m.
The old snowpack will be in most cases well bonded.
Snow depths vary greatly at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions, depending on the infuence of the wind.
At low and intermediate altitudes only a little snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Some snow will fall on Tuesday. The danger will persist.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Individual avalanche prone locations for dry avalanches are to be found in particular on very steep shady slopes. In addition individual gliding avalanches and snow slides are possible.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The new snow and wind slabs of the last few days can be released by a single winter sport participant in isolated cases in particular on very steep shady slopes above the tree line, caution is to be exercised in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in pass areas. These places are sometimes covered with new snow and are therefore difficult to recognise. Mostly avalanches are only small.

On steep grassy slopes small to medium-sized gliding avalanches and snow slides are possible as a consequence of the new snow.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Some snow will fall on Monday. The wind will be moderate adjacent to ridgelines.

The fresh and older wind slabs are lying on soft layers on near-ridge shady slopes.

Only a little snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Individual avalanche prone locations for dry avalanches are to be found on very steep shady slopes. Individual gliding avalanches and snow slides are possible, but they will be mostly small.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Weakly bonded old snow is to be evaluated with care and prudence. Precarious weak layers exist in the old snowpack in gullies and bowls.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Individual mostly small avalanches are possible above approximately 1800 m. This applies especially in gullies and bowls.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The old snowpack remains subject to considerable local variations. At high altitude only a little snow is lying. At high altitude mostly small wind slabs formed. In gullies and bowls the wind slabs are larger.
